quotes.topic_title: Cold open: speed and quality aren’t a trade-off
quotes.text: People talk about this as if there were a trade-off because when they think about speed, the thing they over-index on is rushing or being sloppy. What they should be indexing on is being really competent.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Reframes the speed-vs-quality debate into a competence problem teams can actively invest in.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: speed and quality aren’t a trade-off
quotes.text: If you look at people who are at the pinnacle of their craft, you can basically tell how good the output is going to be of their work product by how fast they're going.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Offers a counterintuitive heuristic: in expert hands, speed can be a leading indicator of quality.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: speed and quality aren’t a trade-off
quotes.text: What it really looks like is you have some rough time budget for how long you think something's going to take. By the time 10% of it has passed, after week one, you have something that works that tests some kind of key hypothesis internally.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Gives a concrete execution method for moving fast: validate a key hypothesis with a working internal prototype early (at ~10% of the timeline).

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: speed and quality aren’t a trade-off
quotes.text: The stuff that we absolutely have to say no to is the exact kind of thing that leads to this bloatedness that makes ICs hate their lives.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product discipline: proactively rejecting certain feature requests to prevent bloat and protect developer experience.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: speed and quality aren’t a trade-off
quotes.text: My goal is to feel bad in the same way that customers feel bad.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A memorable empathy standard for customer discovery: dig until you viscerally understand the user’s pain.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In my conversation with Nan, he shares a system that he uses for being creative and coming up with non-obvious solutions to customer problems, why it's a red flag to him when PMs tell him there's a trade-off between speed and quality, how he talks to customers in order to figure out the emotion that they want to avoid and then figure out the solution to avoiding that emotion, plus some killer advice on how to land a job, including how he landed his job at Linear and his previous role at Mode, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A dense preview of multiple actionable tactics and mental models Nan uses (creativity system, speed vs. quality, emotion-first customer discovery, and job-search advice).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You rarely see the kind of love that people have for Linear for any enterprise B2B SaaS product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive outcome—deep product love in enterprise B2B—setting up why Linear’s approach is worth studying.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Over 150,000 businesses, including 8 of the top 10 largest tech companies globally use Sinch's API to build messaging, email, and calling into their products, and there's something big happening in messaging that product teams to know about, Rich Communication Services, or RCS.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point and flags RCS as a notable shift product teams should track.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Think of RCS as SMS 2.0.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable shorthand mental model for understanding what RCS is and why it matters.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 150,000 businesses, including 8 of the top 10 largest tech companies globally use Sinch's API to build messaging, email, and calling into their products, and there's something big happening in messaging that product teams to know about, Rich Communication Services, or RCS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch)
quotes.context: Strong adoption data point plus a concrete trend (RCS) that product teams can prioritize and plan for.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of RCS as SMS 2.0.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch)
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that quickly explains RCS’s positioning and why it matters.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: US carriers are starting to adopt RCS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch)
quotes.context: A specific market-timing signal that can inform roadmap sequencing and go-to-market planning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Integrations are the foundation, but building all these integrations in-house will cost you years of engineering, time you don't have given the fast pace of AI.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Paragon)
quotes.context: A practical build-vs-buy argument framed around opportunity cost and AI-driven urgency.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Leading AI companies like AI21, You.com, 11x, and coffee.ai are already shipping new integrations seven times faster with Paragon, keeping their engineers focused on core product development.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Paragon)
quotes.context: Concrete example and performance claim that supports the case for using integration infrastructure to accelerate delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Why people want to switch from Jira
quotes.text: The number one answer by far is people want to switch from Jira to Linear.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete data point signaling strong pull-based demand and product-market fit in a notoriously sticky B2B category.

quotes.topic_title: Why people want to switch from Jira
quotes.text: "Linear's design is obviously an industry benchmark, but moreover, the performance and speed is a massive productivity boost."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical differentiation lever—speed/performance—as a direct driver of user productivity and preference.

quotes.topic_title: Why people want to switch from Jira
quotes.text: If you think about the entire impetus behind why Linear was started, it's because Karri was sitting at Coinbase and Airbnb and these places and just watching everyone around him struggle using the tools that they had available and always incumbent tools and just seeing that it made people hate their day-to-day a little bit, and we all got into technology and design and engineering, all this kind of stuff because it was fun.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A product discovery method: observe daily friction with incumbent tools and target emotional pain (“hate their day-to-day”) rather than only feature gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Why people want to switch from Jira
quotes.text: and then to have all of this kind of stuff put these big speed bumps into our day-to-day workflow, it just was really sad. So, that's why we started Linear. This really bust through all of that.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A clear product principle: remove workflow “speed bumps” to restore flow and enjoyment, not just add functionality.

quotes.topic_title: Why people want to switch from Jira
quotes.text: What I love about Linear, I feel like it's an inspirational business because many people want to, "I'm going to build just a much better version of something," and often that doesn't actually work out.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that “better product” alone often isn’t sufficient—useful for practitioners evaluating differentiation and go-to-market risk.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing fast, high-quality product iteration
quotes.text: People talk about this as if there were a trade-off almost in a naive way because when they think about speed, the thing they over index on is rushing or being sloppy, and what they should be indexing on is being really competent or being like an expert.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Reframes “speed vs. quality” as a competence problem (expertise enables both), challenging a common assumption teams use to justify slowness.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing fast, high-quality product iteration
quotes.text: Speed... What it really looks like is you have some rough time budget for how long you think something's going to take, and by the time 10% of it has passed, you have a workable solution.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operational definition of speed: a 10% rule for producing a usable prototype early enough to steer the project.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing fast, high-quality product iteration
quotes.text: And you don't want to wait until you're 80% done to be able to make that kind of judgment because then it's just too late. Then you're pushing deadlines out, and you're making your marketing team very sad.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Explains the cost of late validation and why early hypothesis-testing prevents schedule slip and downstream coordination pain.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing fast, high-quality product iteration
quotes.text: We don't have any expectation that the first version of it is going to be great. That is not in the cards.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Sets a cultural norm that removes perfectionism as a blocker, enabling faster iteration without conflating V1 with the final bar.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing fast, high-quality product iteration
quotes.text: What matters is you have working software that you can interact with, and you can see if it feels good. Does it actually solve the core problem that is facing our users?
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Prioritizes interactive learning and core problem validation over polish, guiding teams toward smallest-learning-unit iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive rollout: internal, beta groups, then GA
quotes.text: We have a gradually increasing sort of circle of users that use every single feature.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A simple rollout framework: expand exposure in concentric circles so every feature is exercised by real users before GA.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive rollout: internal, beta groups, then GA
quotes.text: So, the first circle is just internal users.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Actionable sequencing advice: start with dogfooding as the initial gate before involving external customers.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive rollout: internal, beta groups, then GA
quotes.text: If no one engages with it, if no one's using it, then that's a good signal that we didn't really hit the mark,
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A clear success metric for early releases: engagement is the fastest validation signal, and lack of it is decisive feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive rollout: internal, beta groups, then GA
quotes.text: get new feature, product ideas out to people as early as possible, say, in the first 10% of the amount of time you've allotted, and then release it increasingly to more and more people to get feedback.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete operating rule (“first 10%”) for reducing wasted build time by front-loading real-user feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive rollout: internal, beta groups, then GA
quotes.text: most wasted time is on building things nobody actually ends up wanting or using.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A blunt reminder of the core risk in product development, motivating progressive rollout and early validation.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding bloat by saying no to reporting-driven customization
quotes.text: And the stuff that we absolutely have to say no to is also the exact kind of thing that leads to this bloatedness that makes ICs hate their lives, and it's very specific. It's customization features requested by middle managers in order to make reporting a little bit easier at the cost of making IC workflows worse.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A crisp decision rule for avoiding product bloat: reject reporting-driven customization that harms core IC workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding bloat by saying no to reporting-driven customization
quotes.text: It's like if it fits that description, we're just saying, "No." There's no debate because we've already thought about it and this is the thing that we can't take a single step down this path.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Shows how to operationalize principles into a hard policy that prevents incremental erosion of product quality.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding bloat by saying no to reporting-driven customization
quotes.text: The whole premise is wrong because the moment you start going down this path, and you make the IC user experience worse, they're just going to disengage.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive argument that reporting features can backfire by reducing the very engagement needed to generate reliable data.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding bloat by saying no to reporting-driven customization
quotes.text: There's nine choices. I don't know what any of them meet, so I'm just going to pick one at random. I'm still going to pick the first one.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Concrete example of how forced fields and over-customization degrade data quality and make reporting misleading.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise growth without compromising the product
quotes.text: There are basic scaling things, like we had to make SAML and SCIM and that kind of stuff. It's like, "Yeah, sure, we're going to do those sorts of, like keep the lights on type of work," but when it comes to work that's related to the actual business logic of the app's value proposition, what buyers care about is, is this going to make their team more effective?
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A practical prioritization framework: do required enterprise “plumbing,” but protect the core product value proposition and optimize for team effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise growth without compromising the product
quotes.text: And especially with large companies, right? The current situation we're in is a mess, and if we can convince them that these types of things are actually the reason that it's a mess, then we can really navigate them out of wanting them in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A contrarian enterprise-sales/product move: reframe requested features as causes of dysfunction and guide buyers away from them.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise growth without compromising the product
quotes.text: The first three are the things that really matter to us. If we solve the first three, then the other stuff, we can negotiate on.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A negotiation method for enterprise asks: force prioritization, then over-deliver on the top few needs and treat the rest as tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise growth without compromising the product
quotes.text: I also think that with this particular category of tool, and with a lot of other B2B software, not... Like no means not now, right?
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A memorable sales/PM mental model: treat “no” as timing, keep the relationship warm, and revisit as constraints change.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise growth without compromising the product
quotes.text: Growth in enterprise has been leading the other segments because I think this year, especially we reached a tipping point where I think with software, so much of the buying decision is based on almost like a brand thing, like is this for us?
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A concrete growth observation: enterprise adoption can hinge on brand credibility and identity fit, not just feature checklists.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear debates features: real people, real workflows
quotes.text: I think the complicated debates are often when we do add a new native feature, do we extend an existing feature and make it more powerful or do we add a new sort of service? And a big part of that is trying to figure out exactly who's going to use it, what are the actual real life use cases that we know about? Like that I know that Bob from Company X has this workflow and this is how it would work for him. Here are the different variations where it would work.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A concrete decision frame for feature debates: extend primitives vs add a new service, grounded in known real workflows.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear debates features: real people, real workflows
quotes.text: Yeah, specific person. Yeah. Yeah, exactly. Not a hypothetical person. Not one that you made up like Alice, Bob, or whatever. It's like, "No, here's the first name, last name. Here's their email. You can ask them," and I think that being able to tie it all the way back to reality in that way is a big part of how we really think about and discuss these things.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A practitioner-friendly standard for product discussions: anchor decisions to reachable, named users rather than personas.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear debates features: real people, real workflows
quotes.text: Yeah. I think a trap that a lot of times PMs will fall into is they'll make something, and they'll make some choices in it because maybe it's beautiful or it's elegant, but they don't go the step of like, "Is reality also beautiful and elegant?" Because reality is ugly sometimes, and if you have a beautiful and elegant solution that doesn't match with reality, it doesn't really matter. People can look at it, and they can ooh and ah, but if they don't use it to get their work done, it's never going to have long-term staying power.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A counterweight to over-optimizing for elegance: usefulness depends on fitting messy real-world workflows.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear debates features: real people, real workflows
quotes.text: So, this happens way in the first bit of the life of a particular feature. You release a thing, and then you start getting feedback about it, about hey, it doesn't quite fit reality, and then you ask yourself like, "Did we test that aspect of it? Did we actually match that part to reality?" And if you didn't, then it's like that's the part where you don't actually need that many pieces of feedback against it. It's not really a volume thing. It's like, "Did we think about this right or wrong?"
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A methodology for interpreting feedback early: prioritize correcting wrong mental models over counting requests.

quotes.topic_title: How Linear debates features: real people, real workflows
quotes.text: Another category is just you're getting a request for maybe a very big feature or a feature set from a lot of different people, but then you dig in, and you try to say like, "Okay. Well, tell me about how you're trying to use this," and there's 100 different use cases. So, you have choices here. You can either build the big feature that covers all the long tail of use cases or you can try to see if there's really concentrated pools of use cases for this that really make a lot of sense to adopt as a first order type of feature.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A practical way to handle broad demand: decompose “big feature” requests into concentrated use-case clusters vs long-tail coverage.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Customer Requests instead of custom fields
quotes.text: For B2B companies, this is very relevant, and the reason we did this is because we kept getting this request for fully customized fields, and we would be like, "Well, what is it that you want with your custom fields?" Because the problem is you add 100 custom fields and all your ICs start hating it.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Highlights the anti-pattern of blindly adding custom fields and the importance of probing for the underlying job-to-be-done.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Customer Requests instead of custom fields
quotes.text: And 40% of them were because, "Well, I have a customer," like Walmart or whatever, right? Like, "Walmart asked for this feature, and it's really important. I need everyone to know that Walmart needs this. I need to track it. I need to see how have we report... "
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing that many “custom fields” requests are actually customer-attribution and tracking needs.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Customer Requests instead of custom fields
quotes.text: It's like, "Okay, instead of that, we're going to hook up with your customer support tools. We're going to hook up with your CRNs. We're going to automatically bring in feedback from these companies. We're going to analyze the emails where they're from, and then if someone requests a feature that gets escalated into engineering, it'll just be tagged with whoever asked for it. You don't have to do anything, but you will know, and you can still report on this stuff, but there's nothing about this that makes ICs lives harder.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A methodology for solving reporting/visibility needs via integrations and automation rather than manual tagging workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Customer Requests instead of custom fields
quotes.text: In fact, it makes them feel more confident because when they're building the thing, they actually understand who's asking for it and exactly what the email said.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Connects customer context directly to execution quality by increasing builder confidence and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: Customer Requests instead of custom fields
quotes.text: Most of the time you're going to build this custom field. Something that your head of sales shared with me is how impressed he is with the way you ask questions on customer calls and just keep digging and digging until you get to something that is an insight for you, and then you start to try to solve the problem for them and think about what the product might be, and I think this is such an important and underappreciated skill for PMs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes a repeatable PM skill: persistent questioning to uncover insights instead of implementing the literal request.

quotes.topic_title: Customer calls: dig for emotions to find real problems
quotes.text: my goal is to feel bad in the same way that customers feel bad.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A concrete, memorable definition of empathy in discovery that guides how to probe beyond feature requests.

quotes.topic_title: Customer calls: dig for emotions to find real problems
quotes.text: What is the actual emotional valence that is motivating whatever you're telling me?
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A practical prompt for uncovering the emotional driver behind a request so you can size severity and build the right solution.

quotes.topic_title: Customer calls: dig for emotions to find real problems
quotes.text: So, I don't ever want to put dates on things ever again. So, like, "Okay, cool. We can help you deal with that. If that's what you're feeling, then I can start building stuff to make sure that you never have to have that bad feeling again."
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Shows how translating a painful moment into an emotional job-to-be-done can directly inform what to build.

quotes.topic_title: Customer calls: dig for emotions to find real problems
quotes.text: So, the thing that we did specifically to solve this was on projects in Linear, you can just specify a target date at whatever level of granularity you want. You can say it's a December project. You can say it's a Q4 project. You can say it's a second half of 2024 project. Like whatever you're happy promising, you can just put it on there and that way you never feel like you have to give this sense of false precision so that it ends up with a whole bunch of miscommunication down the line.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A specific product tactic (flexible date granularity) that solves cross-team conflict caused by false precision in commitments.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional hooks and schlep blindness in competitive markets
quotes.text: I think the more competitive your industry is, the more the low-hanging goal-oriented stuff is already picked because every PM from every one of these companies has been asking like, "Well, what's your goal? What is your job to be done," and all this kind of stuff.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A contrarian take that in crowded markets, standard JTBD/goal framing becomes table stakes and stops differentiating products.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional hooks and schlep blindness in competitive markets
quotes.text: So, you have to look at things from an angle that other people might not have seen and for me, and for us, it's the angle of where are the emotional hooks that you're experiencing as you go through your work day, as you use our product, as you use competitors' products?
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A practical product discovery lens: map emotional moments across the workday (including competitor usage) to find differentiation opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional hooks and schlep blindness in competitive markets
quotes.text: You can see where are you feeling bad throughout your day where you don't even know? You might think, "I hate Mondays." "Why do you hate Mondays?" "Well, on Mondays, I have to go out and gather a whole bunch of stuff to write this report that it's really annoying." "Oh, so if I gave you a button that made the report, would that help?" It's like, "Oh, yeah, then I might not hate Monday so much."
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A concrete example of tracing a recurring negative emotion to a specific workflow pain and turning it into an automation opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional hooks and schlep blindness in competitive markets
quotes.text: So, I think Paul Graham has a word for this. He calls it schlep blindness, right? It's like I'm schlepping through life, and I'm just completely blind to it, and it's true.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for hidden, normalized friction that users stop noticing—prime territory for product improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Emotional hooks and schlep blindness in competitive markets
quotes.text: So, there's all of these bad feelings that people are having. They all have the same root cause, which is like there wasn't a very automated organized way to deal with your triage queue.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Shows how to unify multiple user complaints/emotions into a single root cause, guiding what to build (automation + organization).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, the first is get something out as quickly as possible, say, in the first 10% of the time that you have to build this thing and get it out to internal users and then maybe a growing list of beta users and people that are aware of they're using early stuff.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete rule-of-thumb for shipping early and expanding feedback loops from internal to beta users.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Two is prioritize the IC and the user, basically, versus the buyer or the middle manager that wants reporting and all these custom features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counter-positioning strategy for B2B products: optimize for end users over purchasers and managerial stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Three is when you hear asks for features and requests, get to the specific person using the thing, not just general, "Okay, cool. I've heard it 100 times."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical method for handling feature requests by tracing them to real user pain rather than aggregating hearsay.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Find the person that actually needs this thing and understand what's going on, and then four is look for people feeling bad in a moment working in the product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A two-part discovery heuristic: identify the true request originator and hunt for moments of user frustration as product opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Recap and nuance: incentives, mental models, and backlog shaping
quotes.text: There's a nuance which is find where the incentives are really misaligned amongst your user base.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A sharper lens than “focus on the user”: explicitly map incentive conflicts between different user groups to guide product trade-offs.

quotes.topic_title: Recap and nuance: incentives, mental models, and backlog shaping
quotes.text: There's a middle manager that wants really detailed reporting and there's a IC who just really doesn't want to go through all those extra steps, and the incentives for what they want are just very... They're just very misaligned, and you have to find those situations and be pretty judicious about how you make those trade-offs and where you can really find win-win outcomes there.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Concrete example of incentive misalignment (manager vs IC) and a call to deliberately design for win-wins rather than blindly satisfying requests.

quotes.topic_title: Recap and nuance: incentives, mental models, and backlog shaping
quotes.text: So, that anytime you do more research, talk to customers, it's informing your view of the person, and then you're like, "Oh, this was different from what I imagined," or, "Oh wow. This is exactly what we've been thinking and let's build that."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A mental-model-driven approach to research: update your model of the customer first, then decide what to build.

quotes.topic_title: Recap and nuance: incentives, mental models, and backlog shaping
quotes.text: At any given moment, we have probably 20 or 30 opportunities that we could possibly explore, just product opportunities, like problems to solve, areas to improve for our users, but they're not ready yet.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A specific backlog-management data point that normalizes keeping many “not ready” opportunities while conviction is built.

quotes.topic_title: Recap and nuance: incentives, mental models, and backlog shaping
quotes.text: So, what we try to do is identify areas that we might attack with a product, but also keep an up-to-date analysis of each of those areas so that everyone can engage with it and also contribute.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A practical methodology for making customer mental models shareable: maintain living analyses per opportunity so the whole team can align and add insight.

quotes.topic_title: Example opportunity: capacity planning and scoping the solution
quotes.text: All the solutions out there are bad. The best solution is a very, very custom spreadsheet that someone would make, and it's a lot of upkeep.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete, widespread pain point and the current “best available” workaround, signaling a ripe product opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Example opportunity: capacity planning and scoping the solution
quotes.text: So, we have some ideas about how we might automate this, how we might use existing data within Linear to really help out with this problem, but I don't think we've quite cracked it yet.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Models a pragmatic approach: start from data you already have, but resist shipping until the solution is genuinely clear.

quotes.topic_title: Example opportunity: capacity planning and scoping the solution
quotes.text: So, we're continuously developing this, and as we hear from hear from users that are struggling with this problem, we will get on a call with them and sit down with them and talk through it.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: Describes a repeatable discovery method—ongoing iteration fueled by direct user conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Example opportunity: capacity planning and scoping the solution
quotes.text: I think a lot of building conviction around stuff is not even like do we have a workable solution? It's like how much of the problem should we actually take on? Because if we take on too much of the problem, then we'll end up overpromising and not being able to deliver on it.
quotes.speaker: Nan Yu
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product-scoping mental model: conviction is about choosing the right slice of the problem, not just feasibility.
